facts.text: The appellant is a Strawboard Mill. The respondent was in the employ of the appellant.

On August 12, 1959, the respondent was given certain orders by the Technical Director of the appellant, but he refused to comply with them. The same day the respondent refused to comply with certain similar orders given by the machine-man.
On August 13, 1959, he refused to obey similar orders of the shift in-charge.
On August 14, 1959, he refused to obey similar orders of another shift in-charge.

Consequently a notice was served on the respondent to show cause why he should not be dealt with under cl. 22(a) of the Standing Orders which provided that wilful insubordination or disobedience of any lawful orders of superior was misconduct. The respondent submitted his explanation.
He was then suspended and a charge-sheet was served on him on August 16, 1959. Thereafter an inquiry was held into the alleged misconduct.

After the inquiry was over the appellant referred the matter for the decision of the Labour Commissioner without giving any prior decision of its own as provided in cl. 30 of the Standing Orders. The Labour Commissioner refused to give a decision and informed the appellant that it could take such action as it was entitled to under the Standing Orders.
The appellant again approached the Labour Commissioner, but he finally refused to pass any order and directed the appellant to take such action as it thought fit.
Thereupon the appellant dismissed the respondent on February 1, 1960.
Two disputes were pending between the appellant and its workmen: one before the Industrial Tribunal No. 3 at Allahabad and the other before the Labour Court at Meerut.
The appellant sent applications by post on February 1, 1960 to the two authorities for approval of the action taken, namely, the dismissal of the respondent.
The tribunal at Allahabad approved of the action on March 22, 1960.
The Labour Court at Meerut refused to approve the action on April 29, 1960, even though the order passed by the tribunal at Allahabad was brought to its notice.

The Labour Court held that the appellant was not motivated by victimisation. It further held that in the inquiry held by the appellant, prima facie case had been made out for the dismissal of the respondent.

The Labour Court refused to approve the dismissal on the ground that the application for approval had been made after the respondent had already been dismissed, therefore it held that the application was not bona fide.
The application at Meerut was received on February 3, 1960 and at Allahabad on February 4, 1960.

legal_issues.text: Whether under the proviso to s. 6-E(2)(b) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act (same as s. 33(2)(b) of the Industrial Disputes Act), the employer must make an application for approval before dismissing the workman, or can dismiss first and apply simultaneously thereafter.

petitioner_arguments.text: The application for approval can be made after the dismissal, as long as it is simultaneous and part of the same transaction, along with payment of one month's wages.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s. 33(2)(b) Industrial Disputes Act; Form K under r.60; s.33A

respondent_arguments.text: The words 'action taken' in the proviso mean action proposed to be taken; application must be made before dismissal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s. 33(2)(b) Industrial Disputes Act

court_reasoning.text: The proviso allows the employer to discharge or dismiss before obtaining approval, subject to paying one month's wages and making application for approval of the action taken simultaneously as part of the same transaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interpretation harmonizes sub-s.(1) and sub-s.(2); 'approval of the action taken' implies action has occurred; distinguishes from 'permission' in sub-s.(1) and (3).

court_reasoning.text: If tribunal refuses approval, the dismissal falls and workman is deemed never to have been dismissed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for specific reinstatement provision; protects workman via s.33A.

court_reasoning.text: Application must be made without delay, as part of same transaction; depends on facts of each case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In this case, applications sent by post on same day as dismissal, received 2-3 days later, complies.

court_reasoning.text: Disagrees with Bombay HC in Premier Automobiles (application before action) and agrees with Calcutta HC in Metal Press Works (simultaneous).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to read 'proposed' into 'action taken'.

holdings.text: Employer may pass order of dismissal or discharge before obtaining approval, provided one month's wages paid/tendered and application for approval made simultaneously without delay as part of same transaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Premier Automobiles Limited v. Ramchandra Bhimayya
precedents_cited.relevance: Held application must be before action; Court disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Extractions Private Limited v. A. V. Vyan
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Bombay view with hesitation; Court disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Metal Press Works Limited v. Deb R.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held payment and application simultaneous with dismissal; correct view.

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso interpreted; identical to Industrial Disputes Act s.33(2)(b)

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso to s.33(2)(b) allows dismissal first then approval application; distinguishes from permission under s.33(1),(3); s.33A protects if contravened.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Labour Court set aside; action of dismissal by appellant approved.

key_quotes.text: "the employer may pass an order of dismissal or discharge before obtaining the approval of the authority concerned and at the same time make an application for approval of the action taken by him."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of proviso to s.33(2)(b).

key_quotes.text: "If the tribunal does not approve of the action taken by the employer, the result would be that the action taken by him would fall and thereupon the workman would be deemed never to have been dismissed or discharged."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains consequence of non-approval, protecting workman.
